resources.string:
In this lesson, you are going to learn basics of percentage and application of percentage in different contexts. Concept of percentage forms the basic unit of arithmetic This lesson consists of 7 pages besides the assignment and assessment. It covers approximately 5% of the course. You need to plan your time so that you can complete the whole course on schedule. If the course is instructor driven, this lesson should take around 2 hours to discuss. On the other hand, if you are doing self-study, this lesson would require around 4 hours to complete. After understanding the concepts and the solved examples, you must put in around 4-5 hours in practicing the various types of problems in the topic. Think about the learning outcomes as a guide to what you should focus on while studying this lesson.
Upon completion of this lesson, you will be able to: es Understand what is Percentage Learn to do the percentage calculations Know the different types of problems in percentage Learn to solve the problems in the most effective way Apply the formula for Successive Percentage Change
Percentage: When a quantity is expressed out of 100, it is known as Percentage. For example - if a student has scored 400 out of 600 total marks, then student’s percentage marks = 400/600100 = 66.66%. It means that – had the full marks been 100, this student would have achieved 66.66 marks.
Percentage is represented by the symbol ‘%’.

Number is “a numeral or group of numerals”. In this lesson, you will learn different types of numbers and divisibility rules of natural numbers. It is important for the students to understand the different types of numbers as it forms the base for all questions that will follow.

This lesson consists of 9 pages besides the assignment and assessment. It is approximately 5% of the whole course. It is advisable to plan your time in such a way that you complete the whole course within this timeline. If the course is instructor driven, this lesson should take around 1.5 hours to discuss. On the other hand, if you are doing self study, this lesson would require around 3 hours to complete. After understanding the concepts and the solved examples, you must put in around 4-5 hours in practicing the various types of problems in the topic.When you go through the learning outcomes, keep in your mind that these are the final objectives to be derived while studying this lesson.

"After completion of this lesson, you will be able to:

" "• Understand different types of numbers
" "• Know the classification of numbers
" "• Understand divisibility rules of different numbers
" "• Learn to solve problems in the most effective way
"

"If a number can be expressed as a fraction (p/q) where p and q are integers and q≠0, then the number is known as Rational Number. The term ‘rational’ originates from the word ratio, simply because the rational numbers can be written in the format of a ratio.

"
"For example – 2/5, 4/7, 23/4 etc are rational numbers. Rational numbers can be positive as well as negative.

" "Irrational Numbers

" "Any real number that is not rational is irrational. In other words, an irrational number cannot be written as a fraction p/q for any integer p and q.
" "Most famous irrational number is 2, also known as Pythagoras's constant.

" "Integers

" "Any real number that does not have a decimal is an integer. Integers can be either positive or negative or zero. For example: 2, 3, -10, -22, o0 etc are integers.
" "Integers are also classified as Odd or even integers.
" "Even Integers – An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N is known as an even integer, where N is an integer. In other words, any number that is divisible by 2 is an even integer. For example: 2, 4, 100 etc.
" "Odd Integers – An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N +1 is known as an odd integer, where N is an integer. For example 1, 5, 101, -23 are odd integers.
" "Following calculations can be done between Odd and Even integers:

" "Odd ± Odd = Even
" "Even ± Even = Even
" "Odd ± Even = Odd
" "Even ± Odd = Odd
" "(Even)Odd = Even
" "(Odd)Even = Odd
" "Natural Number

" "Natural numbers are numbers used in counting: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5................upto infinity. Natural numbers are also known as positive integers.
" Lowest natural number = 1.

" Whole Numbers
When 0 is added to the set of natural numbers, we obtain whole numbers. So whole numbers are 0,1,2,3,4,5,................upto infinity. Whole numbers are also known as Non-negative integers. Lowest whole number = 0 Prime Number –
Any number that has exactly two distinct factors is known as prime number. In other words, any number which is divisible by 1 and itself only is known as a prime number. For example –: 2 is a prime number, because 2 is divisible by 1 and 2 only (two distinct factors only). Lowest Prime Number 2 Composite Number – Composite numbers are all the natural numbers which are greater than one and are not prime numbers. In other words, composite numbers are those numbers which will have atleast one factor other than 1 and itself. Hence composite numbers will have atleast 3 factors. Lowest composite number = 4. Remember that 1 is neither Prime number nor composite number. Real Number Line Real number line (in short also known as number line) consists of the union of the rational and irrational numbers. Every real number can be shown with a single point on the real number line as shown in image 1.1.

"
Types of Number and their definition: Numbers can be defined to be of two types – Real Number and Imaginary Number. Real number – Real number can be expressed on the number line. In other words, all the real numbers can be felt or experienced in the real world. Imaginary number – In contrast to Real numbers, Imaginary numbers cannot be plotted on the number line and they cannot be felt or experienced in the real world. "

"
If a number can be expressed as a fraction (p/q) where p and q are integers andq≠0, then the number is known as Rational Number. The term ‘rational’ originates from the word ratio, simplybecause the rational numbers can be written in the format of a ratio.
For example – 2/5, 4/7, 23/4 etc are rational numbers. Rational numbers can be positive as well as negative.
Irrational Numbers
Any real number that is not rational is irrational. In other words, an irrational number cannot be written as a fraction p/q for any integer p and q.
Most famous irrational number isÖ2, also known as Pythagoras's constant.
Integers
Any real number that does not have a decimal is an integer. Integers can be either positive or negative or zero. For example: 2, 3, -10, -22, o0 etc are integers.
Integers are also classified as Odd or even integers.
Even Integers – An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N is known as an even integer, where N is an integer. In other words, any number that is divisible by 2 is an even integer. For example: 2, 4, 100 etc.
Odd Integers – An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N +1 is known as an odd integer, where N is an integer. For example 1, 5, 101, -23 are odd integers.
Following calculations can be done between Odd and Even integers:
Odd ± Odd = Even
Even ± Even = Even
Odd ± Even = Odd
Even ± Odd = Odd
(Even)Odd= Even
(Odd)Even= Odd
Natural Number
Natural numbers are numbers used in counting: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5................upto infinity. Natural numbers are also known as positive integers.
Lowest natural number = 1.
Whole Numbers
When 0 is added to the set of natural numbers, we obtain whole numbers. So whole numbers are 0,1,2,3,4,5,................upto infinity. Whole numbers are also known as Non-negative integers.
Lowest whole number = 0
Prime Number –
Any number that has exactly two distinct factors is known as prime number. In other words, any number which is divisible by 1 and itself only is known as a prime number. For example –: 2 is a prime number, because 2 is divisible by 1 and 2 only (two distinct factors only).
Lowest Prime Number =2
Composite Number –
Composite numbers are all the natural numbers which are greater than one and are not prime numbers. In other words, composite numbers are those numbers which will have atleast one factor other than 1 and itself. Hence composite numbers will have atleast 3 factors.
Lowest composite number = 4.
Remember that 1 is neither Prime number nor composite number.
Real Number Line
Real number line(in short also known as number line) consists of the union of the rational and irrational numbers.
Every real number can be shown with a single point on the real number line as shown in image 1.1."

ul.li: On the left hand side, it extends to – infinity (-) to (+ on the right hand side.
Numbers on the right hand side are always larger than the numbers on the left hand side.

resources.string:
"
Example 1:x, y and z are three odd natural numbers. Which of the following will NOT be an Odd Integer?
(a) x +y +z
(b) x - y +z
(c) x +2y +3z
(d) 2x +3y +4z
Solution:
To solve these questions, it is best to assume the values of x, y and z and verify the options one by one.
Assume x =5, y =3 and z =1
Verifying option (a) x +y +z =5 +3 +1 =9. This is an odd number. Hence option (a) is not the answer.
Verifying option (b) x - y +z =5 - 3 +1 =3. This is an odd number. Hence option (b) is not the answer.
Verifying option (c) x +2y +3z =5 +6 +3 =14. This is an even number. Hence option (c) is the answer.
Verifying option (d) 2x +3y +4z =10 +9 +4 =23. This is an odd number. Hence option (d) is not the answer.
Example 2:p, q, r and s are four natural numbers. Two of these are odd and other two are even, though we do not know which two are even and other two are odd. Which of the following will MUST be an Even Integer?
(a) p +q
(b) p - r
(c) p +q +r - s
(d) 2p +3q +4r
Solution:
At first, note that to solve this question, you will not be able to assume values as question does not provide the exact nature of the numbers a, b, c and d. The only point given is – two of these are Odd and other two are even.
Further, since question is asking for “Must be” an even number, an option can be eliminated if it gets an Odd number at the end.
Let us verify the options one by one:
Option (a) p +q
Option (a) p +q can be an odd number if p is an odd number and q is an even number. Hence option (a) will be eliminated.
Option (b) p - r
Option (b) p - r can be an odd number if p is an odd number and r is an even number. Hence option (b) will be eliminated.
Option (c) p +q +r – s contains two odd numbers and two even numbers. Resultant of two odd numbers will be always even number and resultant of two even numbers will be an even number. Finally resultant of these even numbers will again be an even number. Hence option (c) is the answer.
Option (d) 2p +3q +4r can be an odd number if p is an odd number, q is an odd number and r is an even number. Hence option (d) will be eliminated. "

"
Total number of single digit natural numbers =9. These numbers occur from 1 to 9.
Total number of two-digits natural numbers =90. These numbers occur from 10 to 99.
Total number of three-digits natural numbers =900. These numbers occur from 100 to 999.
It can be generalized now that number of four-digits natural numbers = 9000 and so on.
Example 3:How many times the digits of a computer keyboard will be required to be pressed in typing 1st100 natural numbers?
Solution:
Natural numbers are going to be of single digit, two-digits and three-digits when you write 1st100 natural numbers.
Number of natural numbers of 1 digit = 9 ÞNumber of digits = 9 × 1 = 9
Number of natural numbers of 2 digits = 90 ÞNumber of digits = 90 × 2 = 180
Number of natural numbers of 3 digits = 1 ÞNumber of digits = 1 × 3 = 3
Hence total number of digits used in typing 1st100 natural numbers = 9 + 180 + 3 = 192 "
1.1.2 Counting of Numbers in a range
"If a range of numbers is given, and number of natural numbers in that range is to be counted, then image 1.3 can be used to count the number of natural numbers N: "

"
Using divisibility rules of any number, one can identify if a number is divisible by other number or not, without going through the actual division process.
Following is the list divisibility rules of some of the natural numbers:
A number is divisible by 2 – If unit digit of the number is 0, 2, 4, 6 or 8.
A number is divisible by 3 - If sum of digits of the number is divisible by 3.
A number is divisible by 4 –If number formed by the last two digits of the number is divisible by 4.
A number is divisible by5- If last digit of the number is either 5 or 0.
A number is divisible by6 -If the unit digit of the number is 0 or 2 or 4 or 6 or 8 and sum of all the digits of number is divisible by 3.
A number is divisible by8 – If number formed by the last 3 digits of the number is divisible by 8.
A number is divisible by9 - If sum of digits of the number is divisible by 9.
A number is divisible by10 – If the unit digit of the number is 0.
A number is divisible by11-if the difference between the sum of the digits at the even places and the sum of the digits at the odd places is divisible by 11(zero is divisible by 11).
For example - 4553109 is divisible by 11 as the difference of 4+5+1+9=19 and 5+3+0=8 is 11.
A number is divisible by12 –If a number is divisible by 3 and 4, then the number will be divisible by 12.
A number is divisible by16 - if a number formed by the last 4 digits of the given number is divisible by 16.
Process to define the divisibility rule of any prime number:
Any prime number greater than 5 will end up either in 10N+1 or 10N-1 within its 1st10 multiples. In other words, any prime number greater than 5 will give unit digit either 1 or 9 within its 1st10 multiples.
Step 1: Defining Seed Number of the prime number
This multiple is written in the format of 10N+1 or 10N-1. N is known as the seed of that prime number.Seed numbers are taken negative in case of + 1 and positive in the case of -1. For example – In case of 13, multiples of the format 10N1 = 39, 91
39 = 4 × 10 – 1 ÞSeed No. = 4
91 = 9 × 10 + 1ÞSeed No. = -9
So the seed number of 13 = 4 and (-9).
Step 2: Generating the divisibility rule
If the seed number is N, then the divisibility rule = A + NB and if the seed number = (-N), then the divisibility rule = A – NB
Example 4: A number P is divisible by 6. Which of the following may not be an integer?
(a) P/3 (b) P/2 (c)P/6 (d)P/12
Solution:
Since P is divisible by 6, it will be divisible by all its factors also. Hence P is divisible by 2 and 3 both. Hence option (a), option (b) and option (c) are eliminated. Option (d) P/12 may be or may not be an integer as P may be or may not be divisible by 12.
Hence option (d) is the answer.
Example 5:A number P is divisible by 6 but not divisible by 4. Which of the following will not be an integer?
(a) P/3 (b) P/2 (c) P/6 (d)P/12
Solution: Since P is divisible by 6, it will be divisible by all its factors also. Hence P is divisible by 2 and 3 both. Further, since P is not divisible by 4, hence it will not be divisible by any multiple of 4. So, P will be not divisible by 12, which is a multiple of 4. Hence option (d) is the answer.
Example 6: Which of the following numbers will be divisible by 6?
(a) 236512 (b) 26492 (c) 65139 (d) 47592
Solution:
Using the divisibility rule of 6:
A number is divisible by6 -If unit digit of the number is 0 or 2 or 4 or 6 or 8 and sum of all the digits of number is divisible by 3.
Using “Unit digit of the number is 0 or 2 or 4 or 6 or 8”, option (c) 65139 can be simply eliminated as the unit digit of the number is 9.
Now, summation of all the digits of given number should be divisible by 3.
Let us look at remaining options now:
Option (a) 236512
Sum of digits =2 +3 +6 +5 +1 +2 =19. Since 19 is NOT divisible by 3, hence option (a) is eliminated.
Option (b) 26492
Sum of digits =2 +6 +4 +9 +2 =23. Since 23 is NOT divisible by 3, hence option (b) is eliminated.
Option (d) 47532
Sum of digits =4 +7 +5 +3 +2 =21. Since 21 is divisible by 3, hence option (d) is the answer. "

"
1. All real numbers are of exactly one of the two types: either rational number or irrational number.
2. A rational number is a number that can be expressed as a fraction (p/q) where p and q are integers and q≠0. If a real number is not rational, then it will be compulsorily irrational.
3. Any real number that does not have a decimal is an integer.
4. An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N is known as an even integer, where N is an integer.
5. An integer that can be expressed in the format of 2N +1 is known as an odd integer, where N is an integer.
6. Natural numbers are numbers used in counting: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5................upto infinity. Natural numbers are also known as positive integers.
7. When 0 is added to the set of natural numbers, we obtain whole numbers.
8. Any number that has exactly two distinct factors is known as prime number.
9. Composite numbers are all the natural numbers which are greater than one and are not prime numbers.
10. Total number of single digit natural numbers =9. These numbers occur from 1 to 9.
Total number of two-digits natural numbers =90. These numbers occur from 10 to 99.
Total number of three-digits natural numbers =900. These numbers occur from 100 to 999.
And so on. "

"
To understand the concept of Successive Percentage Change, consider the following example: Bill joined as a management trainee in an organization at a monthly salary of USD 600 in the year 2014. In the year 2015, he got an increment of 25% over his salary in 2014. In the year 2016, he got an increment of 20% over his salary in 2015.
It can be seen that the percentage increment in Bill’s salary occur on the previous year’s salary in 2015 as well as in 2016. So, the increment happens ‘in succession’ for each of the years. In other words, percentage increment in 2016 does NOT happen over his salary in 2014.
This is what we know as Successive Percentage Change.
To find out Bill’s monthly salary in 2016, you can apply either percentage change method one by one for each of the years, or, you can simply use the formula for successive percentage change.
You will see both the methods one by one:
Method 1 – Percentage Change method
Monthly salary in 2014 = USD 600
Monthly salary in 2015 = 25% more than the monthly salary in 2014 = Monthly salary in 2014 + 25% of monthly salary in 2014 = USD 600 + 25% of USD 600 = USD 600 + USD = USD 600 + USD 150 = USD 750
Next, Monthly salary in 2016 = 20% more than the monthly salary in 2015 = Monthly salary in 2015 + 20% of monthly salary in 2015 = USD 750 + 20% of USD 750 = USD 750 + USD = USD 750 + USD 150 = USD 900
Method 2 – Formula for Successive Percentage Change
If there are two successive percentage increase of x% and y%, then net percentage change = (x + y + )%
In the example given above, x = 25% and y = 20%
Then net percentage change = (25 + 20 + )% = 50%
Hence Bill’s monthly salary in 2016 will be 50% more than his monthly salary in 2014.
Bill’s monthly salary in 2016 = Bill’s monthly salary in 2014 + 50% of Bill’s monthly salary in 2016 = USD 600 + 50% of USD 600 = USD 600 + USD = USD 600 + USD 300 = USD 900
Note it! If there is percentage increase, then plus sign (+) will be used; if there is percentage decrease, then minus sign (-) will be used
For example, if there are two successive percentage changes of x% increase and y% decrease, then net percentage change = (x - y + )% = (x - y - )%
Similarly, if there are two successive percentage changes of x% decrease and y% decrease, then net percentage change = (-x - y + )% = (-x - y + )%
Tip In mathematics, multiplication sign is considered as successive percentage change.
Example 5: Length of a rectangle is increased by 20% and its breadth is decreased by 10%. What is the percentage change in area of the rectangle?
Solution:
In this case, there are two successive percentage changes of x% increase and y% decrease, then net percentage change = (x - y + )% = (x - y - )% = 20 – 10 - = 8%
Hence percentage change in the area of rectangle = 8% increase
Example 6: Price of an article is increased by 25%. By what percentage should be consumption be decreased so that expenditure on this article remains the same?
Solution:
It can be seen that Price Consumption = Expenditure
In this question, it is given that price increases by 25%, and finally expenditure should remain the same. This is possible only if consumption is decreased by some certain percentage.
Using successive percentage change formula:
There are two changes:- 25% increase and y% decrease, leading to 0% change finally.
Or, 25 - y – = 0
Or, 25 – y - = 0, or, 25 = y+ =
Hence y = 20%.
So, consumption should be decreased by 20%.
Activity Activity 2.2: Population of a town increases by 10% in the first year, and decreases by 20% in the second year. What is the percentage change in the population of the town during the whole period?
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Summary 1. What percentage of p is q = 100.
2. p% of q = q. It can be seen that p% of q = q% of p
3. Percentage Change = 100 %
4. Successive Percentage Change: If there are two successive percentage increase of x% and y%, then net percentage change = (x + y + )%"

"Material is the metaphor.

"
"A material metaphor is the unifying theory of a rationalized space and a system of motion." "The material is grounded in tactile reality, inspired by the study of paper and ink, yet " "technologically advanced and open to imagination and magic.
" "Surfaces and edges of the material provide visual cues that are grounded in reality. The " "use of familiar tactile attributes helps users quickly understand affordances. Yet the " "flexibility of the material creates new affordances that supercede those in the physical " "world, without breaking the rules of physics.
" "The fundamentals of light, surface, and movement are key to conveying how objects move, " "interact, and exist in space and in relation to each other. Realistic lighting shows " "seams, divides space, and indicates moving parts.

"
"Bold, graphic, intentional.

"
"The foundational elements of print based design typography, grids, space, scale, color, " "and use of imagery guide visual treatments. These elements do far more than please the " "eye. They create hierarchy, meaning, and focus. Deliberate color choices, edge to edge " "imagery, large scale typography, and intentional white space create a bold and graphic " "interface that immerse the user in the experience.
" "An emphasis on user actions makes core functionality immediately apparent and provides " "waypoints for the user.

"
"Motion provides meaning.

"
"Motion respects and reinforces the user as the prime mover. Primary user actions are " "inflection points that initiate motion, transforming the whole design.
" "All action takes place in a single environment. Objects are presented to the user without " "breaking the continuity of experience even as they transform and reorganize.
" "Motion is meaningful and appropriate, serving to focus attention and maintain continuity. " "Feedback is subtle yet clear. Transitions are efﬁcient yet coherent.

"
"3D world.

"
"The material environment is a 3D space, which means all objects have x, y, and z " "dimensions. The z-axis is perpendicularly aligned to the plane of the display, with the " "positive z-axis extending towards the viewer. Every sheet of material occupies a single " "position along the z-axis and has a standard 1dp thickness.
" "On the web, the z-axis is used for layering and not for perspective. The 3D world is " "emulated by manipulating the y-axis.

"
"Light and shadow.

"
"Within the material environment, virtual lights illuminate the scene. Key lights create " "directional shadows, while ambient light creates soft shadows from all angles.
" "Shadows in the material environment are cast by these two light sources. In Android " "development, shadows occur when light sources are blocked by sheets of material at " "various positions along the z-axis. On the web, shadows are depicted by manipulating the " "y-axis only. The following example shows the card with a height of 6dp.

"
"Resting elevation.

"
"All material objects, regardless of size, have a resting elevation, or default elevation " "that does not change. If an object changes elevation, it should return to its resting " "elevation as soon as possible.

"
"Component elevations.

"
"The resting elevation for a component type is consistent across apps (e.g., FAB elevation " "does not vary from 6dp in one app to 16dp in another app).
" "Components may have different resting elevations across platforms, depending on the depth " "of the environment (e.g., TV has a greater depth than mobile or desktop).

"
"Responsive elevation and dynamic elevation offsets.

"
"Some component types have responsive elevation, meaning they change elevation in response " "to user input (e.g., normal, focused, and pressed) or system events. These elevation " "changes are consistently implemented using dynamic elevation offsets.
" "Dynamic elevation offsets are the goal elevation that a component moves towards, relative " "to the component’s resting state. They ensure that elevation changes are consistent " "across actions and component types. For example, all components that lift on press have " "the same elevation change relative to their resting elevation.
" "Once the input event is completed or cancelled, the component will return to its resting " "elevation.

"
"Avoiding elevation interference.

"
"Components with responsive elevations may encounter other components as they move between " "their resting elevations and dynamic elevation offsets. Because material cannot pass " "through other material, components avoid interfering with one another any number of ways, " "whether on a per component basis or using the entire app layout.
" "On a component level, components can move or be removed before they cause interference. " "For example, a floating action button (FAB) can disappear or move off screen before a " "user picks up a card, or it can move if a snackbar appears.
" "On the layout level, design your app layout to minimize opportunities for interference. " "For example, position the FAB to one side of stream of a cards so the FAB won’t interfere " "when a user tries to pick up one of cards.

"
